title: Loan-funded Loans: Asset-like Liabilities inside Bank Holding Companies
speaker: Jennie Bai, McDonough School of Business, Georgetown University
description:
Loan-funded Loans: Asset-like Liabilities inside Bank Holding Companies
with Murillo Campello and Pradeep Muthukrishnan
Abstract:
Leveraging unique regulatory data on internal fund flows between bank holding companies (BHCs) and their subsidiaries, this paper investigates the role of internal loans as an underexplored source of liquidity for commercial banks. Unlike traditional deposits, internal loans serve as asset‐like liabilities that offer banks a stable funding alternative. Our results show that banks with access to internal funding engage more aggressively in the syndicated lending market, originating larger loans with longer maturities and lower spreads while expanding relationships with new, marginal — often financially constrained — borrowers. Although these bank subsidiaries exhibit higher non‐performing loan ratios, the aggregate impact of internal loans on performance is positive. We also show how internal capital allocation decisions differ between bank and nonbank subsidiaries, with nonbanks receiving increasingly preferential treatment over time. Our findings underscore the critical importance of internal capital markets in shaping bank behavior and influencing credit access in the economy while undermining the transmission of monetary policy.
Paper
description_html:
Loan-funded Loans: Asset-like Liabilities inside Bank Holding Companies

with Murillo Campello and Pradeep Muthukrishnan

Abstract:

Leveraging unique regulatory data on internal fund flows between bank holding companies (BHCs) and their subsidiaries, this paper investigates the role of internal loans as an underexplored source of liquidity for commercial banks. Unlike traditional deposits, internal loans serve as asset‐like liabilities that offer banks a stable funding alternative. Our results show that banks with access to internal funding engage more aggressively in the syndicated lending market, originating larger loans with longer maturities and lower spreads while expanding relationships with new, marginal — often financially constrained — borrowers. Although these bank subsidiaries exhibit higher non‐performing loan ratios, the aggregate impact of internal loans on performance is positive. We also show how internal capital allocation decisions differ between bank and nonbank subsidiaries, with nonbanks receiving increasingly preferential treatment over time. Our findings underscore the critical importance of internal capital markets in shaping bank behavior and influencing credit access in the economy while undermining the transmission of monetary policy.

Paper

title: Biased Promotions
speaker: Elena Pikulina
description:
Biased Promotions
Joint with Daniel Ferreira and Radoslawa Nikolowa
Abstract:
We present a model of biased promotions in which firm size, wages, and internal labor markets are endogenously determined in a competitive labor market equilibrium. Workers value both wages and job amenities, and differ only by a non-productive label: “Blue” or “Red.” Firms favor the Blue group in promotions. The equilibrium features partial segregation: large, high-wage firms employ workers from both groups and offer biased promotion opportunities, while small, low-wage firms hire only workers from the unfavored group and offer stable careers. Although individual firms prefer unbiased promotions, biased promotions collectively benefit firms by weakening worker bargaining power. The model endogenizes firm heterogeneity and helps explain why bias-driven gaps in promotions and earnings may persist even in competitive markets.
Paper
description_html:
Biased Promotions

Joint with Daniel Ferreira and Radoslawa Nikolowa

Abstract: 

 

We present a model of biased promotions in which firm size, wages, and internal labor markets are endogenously determined in a competitive labor market equilibrium. Workers value both wages and job amenities, and differ only by a non-productive label: “Blue” or “Red.” Firms favor the Blue group in promotions. The equilibrium features partial segregation: large, high-wage firms employ workers from both groups and offer biased promotion opportunities, while small, low-wage firms hire only workers from the unfavored group and offer stable careers. Although individual firms prefer unbiased promotions, biased promotions collectively benefit firms by weakening worker bargaining power. The model endogenizes firm heterogeneity and helps explain why bias-driven gaps in promotions and earnings may persist even in competitive markets.

Paper

title: Sparse Cryptocurrency Factor Models
speaker: Thilo Leitzbach (GSEFM)
description:
Abstract:
Many empirical asset pricing techniques have spilled over from the equity literature to cryptocurrencies. A cornerstone of that development are adhoc, sparse factor models built on characteristics-sorted long-short portfolios. Anticipating a strengthening of this trend we provide a data-driven perspective on the matter that leverages a large body of research design combinations. We show that the constructed crypto factors are highly dependent on these choice sets with weekly Sharpe ratios varying by more than 0.1 on average. In addition, we analyze two statistical methods to impose sparsity statistically by employing an elastic-net approach and by forming hierarchical clusters of the factors. Our findings indicate that adhoc factor models are successful in explaining the cross-section but miss economically meaningful portfolios that are allocated in the tangency portfolio.
description_html: Abstract: Many empirical asset pricing techniques have spilled over from the equity literature to cryptocurrencies. A cornerstone of that development are adhoc, sparse factor models built on characteristics-sorted long-short portfolios. Anticipating a strengthening of this trend we provide a data-driven perspective on the matter that leverages a large body of research design combinations. We show that the constructed crypto factors are highly dependent on these choice sets with weekly Sharpe ratios varying by more than 0.1 on average. In addition, we analyze two statistical methods to impose sparsity statistically by employing an elastic-net approach and by forming hierarchical clusters of the factors. Our findings indicate that adhoc factor models are successful in explaining the cross-section but miss economically meaningful portfolios that are allocated in the tangency portfolio.

title: Gaming the Giants: How Startups Shape Innovation to Spark Acquisition Wars
speaker: Bruno Jullien (Toulouse School of Economics)

title: Redefining (Legal) Adulthood:The Effects of Lowering the Age of Majority on Women's Postsecondary Education and Family Formation
speaker: Anna Daelen (Federal Institute for Population Research)
description:
Title:
Redefining (Legal) Adulthood: The Effects of Lowering the Age of Majority on Women's Postsecondary Education and Family Formation
Abstract:
We identify the impact of agency in decision-making on women's post-secondary education and family formation outcomes. The reform we investigate lowered the age of legal adulthood from 21 to 18 in 1975 West Germany. Before the reform, academic-track students became legal adults 1-2 years after obtaining university entrance qualification (Abitur), and thus needed formal parent consent to enroll in university. As a consequence of the reform, students became legal adults before obtaining university entrance qualification. Our difference-in-differences model exploits variation in school start cutoff dates that vary between federal states. Holding constant federal state and month of birth, we define treatment status as being legal adult at the predicted time of receiving a university entry degree. Using data from the German Microcensus, we show that women reaching legal adulthood before finishing secondary school are more likely to obtain a postsecondary degree, which is driven by university degrees. On the other side, treated women are less likely to marry and have children. Conditional on being married and cohabitating with their partner, they are more likely to have a partner with a university degree as opposed to having a partner with a vocational degree. Reaching the age of majority earlier thus has lasting effects on major life events and the population composition as a whole.
description_html:
Title: Redefining (Legal) Adulthood: The Effects of Lowering the Age of Majority on Women's Postsecondary Education and Family Formation

Abstract: We identify the impact of agency in decision-making on women's post-secondary education and family formation outcomes. The reform we investigate lowered the age of legal adulthood from 21 to 18 in 1975 West Germany. Before the reform, academic-track students became legal adults 1-2 years after obtaining university entrance qualification (Abitur), and thus needed formal parent consent to enroll in university. As a consequence of the reform, students became legal adults before obtaining university entrance qualification. Our difference-in-differences model exploits variation in school start cutoff dates that vary between federal states. Holding constant federal state and month of birth, we define treatment status as being legal adult at the predicted time of receiving a university entry degree. Using data from the German Microcensus, we show that women reaching legal adulthood before finishing secondary school are more likely to obtain a postsecondary degree, which is driven by university degrees. On the other side, treated women are less likely to marry and have children. Conditional on being married and cohabitating with their partner, they are more likely to have a partner with a university degree as opposed to having a partner with a vocational degree. Reaching the age of majority earlier thus has lasting effects on major life events and the population composition as a whole.

title: Inflation and Floating-Rate Loans: Evidence from the Euro-Area
speaker: Glenn Schepens, ECB
description:
Inflation and Floating-Rate Loans: Evidence from the Euro-Area
with Fabrizio Core, Filippo De Marco, Tim Eisert
Abstract:
We provide novel evidence on the supply-side transmission of monetary policy through a floating-rate channel. After a rate hike, firms with floating-rate loans keep prices elevated to offset higher borrowing costs, thereby reducing the effectiveness of monetary policy. Using monthly data on product-level prices, industry-level inflation rates and the euro-area credit register from 2021 to 2023, we find that the short-run impact of monetary tightening on inflation is 50% smaller when firms rely on floating-rate loans. This effect is stronger for firms that rely more on working capital to finance production and when they can easily pass on higher prices to their sticky customer base (customer capital). To address the selection of firms into floating-rate loans, we exploit bank-side factors in the lending relationship. Firms more exposed to floating-rate loans increase their mark-ups more during the rate tightening, but also see higher funding costs. Overall, if firms across the euro area had a lower reliance on floating-rate loans, inflation would have been 0.8 percentage points lower in 2022-2023.
Paper
description_html:
Inflation and Floating-Rate Loans: Evidence from the Euro-Area

with Fabrizio Core, Filippo De Marco, Tim Eisert

Abstract:

We provide novel evidence on the supply-side transmission of monetary policy through a floating-rate channel. After a rate hike, firms with floating-rate loans keep prices elevated to offset higher borrowing costs, thereby reducing the effectiveness of monetary policy. Using monthly data on product-level prices, industry-level inflation rates and the euro-area credit register from 2021 to 2023, we find that the short-run impact of monetary tightening on inflation is 50% smaller when firms rely on floating-rate loans. This effect is stronger for firms that rely more on working capital to finance production and when they can easily pass on higher prices to their sticky customer base (customer capital). To address the selection of firms into floating-rate loans, we exploit bank-side factors in the lending relationship. Firms more exposed to floating-rate loans increase their mark-ups more during the rate tightening, but also see higher funding costs. Overall, if firms across the euro area had a lower reliance on floating-rate loans, inflation would have been 0.8 percentage points lower in 2022-2023.

title: Intergenerational Mobility by Sexuality
speaker: Mathias Jensen (University of Oxford)

title: Protection of personal data in the digital Euro ecosystem
speaker: Prof. Dr. Andreas Kerkemeyer TU Darmstadt
location: Raum “Commerzbank”, House of Finance, Goethe-Universität Frankfurt

title: If I Were You: Advisor Gender and Client Risk Tolerance
speaker: Dominik Scheld (Goethe University)
description:
Abstract:
We examine how advisor interference shapes clients’ elicited risk tolerance. Exploiting advisor retirement as an exogenous shock in a setting with random client–advisor assignment, we analyze more than 7,000 in-person meetings. We show that clients paired with the same advisor report systematically similar risk tolerance levels, while otherwise comparable clients of different advisors feature systematically different risk tolerance levels. Our findings are consistent with a false consensus effect, whereby advisors project their own preferences onto clients. The effect is strongest for female clients meeting male advisors. Elicited risk preferences matter: they influence subsequent investment recommendations and determine portfolio risk.
description_html: Abstract: We examine how advisor interference shapes clients’ elicited risk tolerance. Exploiting advisor retirement as an exogenous shock in a setting with random client–advisor assignment, we analyze more than 7,000 in-person meetings. We show that clients paired with the same advisor report systematically similar risk tolerance levels, while otherwise comparable clients of different advisors feature systematically different risk tolerance levels. Our findings are consistent with a false consensus effect, whereby advisors project their own preferences onto clients. The effect is strongest for female clients meeting male advisors. Elicited risk preferences matter: they influence subsequent investment recommendations and determine portfolio risk.

speaker: Jordi Llorens-Terrazas (Surrey)

title: Unlocking Mortgage Lock-In: Evidence From  a Spatial Housing Ladder Model
speaker: Pierre Mabille, INSEAD Fontainebleau
description:
Unlocking Mortgage Lock-In: Evidence From  a Spatial Housing Ladder Model
with Julia Fonseca, Lu Liu
Abstract:
Mortgage borrowers are “locked in”: forgoing moves to hold on to low mortgage rates. We study the general equilibrium effects of mortgage lock-in on housing markets and evaluate a policy aimed at unlocking lock-in. We provide evidence that lock-in increases prices relative to a counterfactual where rates reset, particularly in expensive areas, because locked-in borrowers would otherwise have downsized and demanded less housing. We design a spatial housing ladder model with long-term mortgages, generating a distribution of locked-in rates and equilibrium effects on mobility and prices consistent with the data. A temporary rate hike causes lock-in, increasing housing demand and prices relative to a counterfactual without lock-in, especially in expensive areas. A $10k tax credit to starter-home sellers modestly unlocks mobility while increasing trade-up home prices, with the vast majority of transfer recipients being infra-marginal.
Paper
description_html:
Unlocking Mortgage Lock-In: Evidence From a Spatial Housing Ladder Model

with Julia Fonseca, Lu Liu

Abstract:

Mortgage borrowers are “locked in”: forgoing moves to hold on to low mortgage rates. We study the general equilibrium effects of mortgage lock-in on housing markets and evaluate a policy aimed at unlocking lock-in. We provide evidence that lock-in increases prices relative to a counterfactual where rates reset, particularly in expensive areas, because locked-in borrowers would otherwise have downsized and demanded less housing. We design a spatial housing ladder model with long-term mortgages, generating a distribution of locked-in rates and equilibrium effects on mobility and prices consistent with the data. A temporary rate hike causes lock-in, increasing housing demand and prices relative to a counterfactual without lock-in, especially in expensive areas. A $10k tax credit to starter-home sellers modestly unlocks mobility while increasing trade-up home prices, with the vast majority of transfer recipients being infra-marginal.

Paper

title: Persistent Mispricing and Beta Anomaly
speaker: Baris Ince (Goethe University)
description:
Abstract:
The beta anomaly—the negative risk-adjusted return earned by a long-short portfolio on market beta—reverses sign and becomes statistically significant when evaluated against mispricing-based factor models. Among a large set of potential mispricing variables, only those related to equity issuance help to explain the anomaly. Using insights from the literature on equity issuance, we then conclude that the anomaly reflects persistent mispricing. Consequently, we identify persistently high investor sentiment as a key conditioning factor for the existence of the anomaly. Moreover, we show that persistent mispricing serves as an important underlying mechanism linking analyst disagreement and market volatility to the pricing of beta.
description_html: Abstract: The beta anomaly—the negative risk-adjusted return earned by a long-short portfolio on market beta—reverses sign and becomes statistically significant when evaluated against mispricing-based factor models. Among a large set of potential mispricing variables, only those related to equity issuance help to explain the anomaly. Using insights from the literature on equity issuance, we then conclude that the anomaly reflects persistent mispricing. Consequently, we identify persistently high investor sentiment as a key conditioning factor for the existence of the anomaly. Moreover, we show that persistent mispricing serves as an important underlying mechanism linking analyst disagreement and market volatility to the pricing of beta.

title: TBA
speaker: Fabrizio Mazzonna (USI Lugano)

title: Mortgage Structure, Financial Stability, and Risk Sharing
speaker: Lu Liu, The Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania
description:
Mortgage Structure, Financial Stability, and Risk Sharing
with Vadim Elenev
Abstract:
Adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs) expose households to rising payments, increasing defaults, while fixed-rate mortgages (FRMs) expose lenders to greater interest rate risk. We evaluate these competing forces in a quantitative model with flexible mortgage contracts, liquidity-driven household default, and a banking sector with sticky deposits. We find financial stability risks are U-shaped in mortgage fixation length. While FRMs benefit from deposit rate stickiness, ARMs provide net worth hedging by concentrating defaults in states when intermediary net worth is high due to increases in mortgage income. An intermediate fixation length balances these effects, minimizing financial sector volatility and improving aggregate risk sharing.
Paper
description_html:
Mortgage Structure, Financial Stability, and Risk Sharing

with Vadim Elenev

Abstract:

Adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs) expose households to rising payments, increasing defaults, while fixed-rate mortgages (FRMs) expose lenders to greater interest rate risk. We evaluate these competing forces in a quantitative model with flexible mortgage contracts, liquidity-driven household default, and a banking sector with sticky deposits. We find financial stability risks are U-shaped in mortgage fixation length. While FRMs benefit from deposit rate stickiness, ARMs provide net worth hedging by concentrating defaults in states when intermediary net worth is high due to increases in mortgage income. An intermediate fixation length balances these effects, minimizing financial sector volatility and improving aggregate risk sharing.

Paper

title: Changing Jobs to Fight Inflation: Labor Market Reactions to Inflationary Shocks
speaker: Gorkem Bostanci (University of British Columbia)
description:
Title:
Changing Jobs to Fight Inflation: Labor Market Reactions to Inflationary Shocks (with Koru, O. and Villalvazo S.)
Abstract:
We argue that inflationary shocks affect allocative efficiency by changing the rate and the characteristics of workers' job-to-job transitions. First, using monetary policy shocks and survey data on search effort, we empirically show that a one percentage point rise in inflation increases job-to-job transitions by up to 4.5%, and workers with higher inflation expectations are more likely to search and do so more effectively. Second, we build a general equilibrium model of directed on-the-job search to quantify the aggregate implications of labor market reactions. Higher-than-expected inflation reduces real wages, prompting workers to search more actively and aim lower. This increases job-to-job transitions but lowers the efficiency gains per transition. Therefore, the effect on output is ambiguous. Last, we calibrate the model to the U.S. economy. Inflationary shocks increase reallocation rates, yet allocative efficiency and output decline. Small deflationary shocks (e.g., 2%) increase output in the short run, while others decrease it.
description_html:
Title: Changing Jobs to Fight Inflation: Labor Market Reactions to Inflationary Shocks (with Koru, O. and Villalvazo S.)  

Abstract: We argue that inflationary shocks affect allocative efficiency by changing the rate and the characteristics of workers' job-to-job transitions. First, using monetary policy shocks and survey data on search effort, we empirically show that a one percentage point rise in inflation increases job-to-job transitions by up to 4.5%, and workers with higher inflation expectations are more likely to search and do so more effectively. Second, we build a general equilibrium model of directed on-the-job search to quantify the aggregate implications of labor market reactions. Higher-than-expected inflation reduces real wages, prompting workers to search more actively and aim lower. This increases job-to-job transitions but lowers the efficiency gains per transition. Therefore, the effect on output is ambiguous. Last, we calibrate the model to the U.S. economy. Inflationary shocks increase reallocation rates, yet allocative efficiency and output decline. Small deflationary shocks (e.g., 2%) increase output in the short run, while others decrease it.

title: TBA
speaker: Jad Beyhum (KU Leuven)

title: Toward the Unconventional: The Evolution of VC Preferences for Atypical Ventures
speaker: Alexander Vossen (Tilburg University)
description:
Title:
Toward the Unconventional: The Evolution of VC Preferences for Atypical Ventures
Abstract:
Literatures on categorization and strategic differentiation suggest that the effectiveness of an atypical identity or distinct market positioning depends on the preferences of the evaluative audience. However, these preferences are often treated as stable, with heterogeneity assumed only between audiences rather than evolving within them. Our study aims to explain how preferences for atypicality might evolve among venture capitalists, using data on startups and their investments from PitchBook and Crunchbase. We distinguish between two complementary lenses: an experiential perspective, focusing on how prior investment experiences could shape subsequent choices, and a socially constructed perspective, focusing on how network exposure and field embeddedness may influence investment patterns. Our study suggests that VCs’ preferences for unconventional ventures may change over time, indicating that audience preferences are dynamic and context-dependent, rather than fixed markers of evaluation.
description_html:
Title: Toward the Unconventional: The Evolution of VC Preferences for Atypical Ventures

Abstract: Literatures on categorization and strategic differentiation suggest that the effectiveness of an atypical identity or distinct market positioning depends on the preferences of the evaluative audience. However, these preferences are often treated as stable, with heterogeneity assumed only between audiences rather than evolving within them. Our study aims to explain how preferences for atypicality might evolve among venture capitalists, using data on startups and their investments from PitchBook and Crunchbase. We distinguish between two complementary lenses: an experiential perspective, focusing on how prior investment experiences could shape subsequent choices, and a socially constructed perspective, focusing on how network exposure and field embeddedness may influence investment patterns. Our study suggests that VCs’ preferences for unconventional ventures may change over time, indicating that audience preferences are dynamic and context-dependent, rather than fixed markers of evaluation.
